title: Ticket #1302: config-file macro expansion doesn't see param table defaults
description:
Macro expansion in the config file only works for configuration values defined in the config file (or environment). It doesn't work for values that only have a default value from the param table. Instead, it replaces the macro reference with an empty string.

Example: 

LOCK = /var/condor/log
MY_LOCK_FILE = $(LOCK)/MyLockFile

The above case will result in MY_LOCK_FILE being /var/condor/log/MyLockFile. However, if LOCK is not defined in the config file, MY_LOCK_FILE will be /MyLockFile, even if LOCK has a default value in the param table.

One potential issue is how to treat "empty assignment" of configuration values. Example: 

LOCK=
MY_LOCK_FILE = $(LOCK)/MyLockFile

Should the empty assignment override the default from the param table or should it effectively erase any previous assignment of LOCK and reset its value back to the default? I propose that it should be the former, not the latter. So in the above example, MY_LOCK_FILE will be /MyLockFile, even if LOCK has some default in the param table.
remarks:
2010-Mar-22 16:36:31 by matt:
+1 to LOCK= setting LOCK to nothing, not resetting. This maintains the current semantics.
